newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: San Miguel to hold 25 pct C-C Amatil.
newsitem.headline: San Miguel to hold 25 pct C-C Amatil.

text.p: Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd said on Thursday it planned to issue 293 million ordinary shares worth about A$3.4 billion under its plan to merge its soft drink operations with San Miguel Corp of the Philippines.
C-C Amatil said that upon completion of the transaction, San Migel would hold 25 percent of C-C Amatil shares and become its second largest shareholder.
The Coca-Cola Co would remain C-C Amatil's largest shareholder with 33 percent.

C-C Amatil said that under the proposal San Miguel subsidiary Coca-Cola Bottlers Philippines Inc (CCPBI) would combine with C-C Amatil to create the largest Coca- Cola bottling group outside the United States.
CCPBI, 70 percent owned by San Miguel and 30 percent by The Coca-Cola Co, had sales of A$1.2 billion in 1996.
CC-Amatil chairman Dean Wills said the transaction was expected to be completed by mid-1997.
"The prospect of the expansion of CC-Amatil's interests into another major market in Asia is an exciting opportunity," Wills told shareholders at the annual general meeting.
Wills said upon completion of the transaction, CCPBI would become a wholly owned subsidary of CC-Amatil.
He said the transaction would "add immediately and substantially to CCA's earnings and growth prospects".
San Miguel chairman and chief executive officer Andres Soriano said in a statement that the move allowed San Miguel to expand the horizon of its soft drinks business.
San Miguel is the Philippines' largest beverage, food and packaging company.
The Coca-Cola Co chairman Roberto Goizueta said the combined strength of C-C Amatil and San Miguel would create one of the world's most powerful bottling systems.
C-C Amatil last year placed about 9.3 percent of its shares with Robert Kuok's Hong Kong-based Kerry Group.
